facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 500 of 1957 was filed by special leave against the judgment and order dated September 11, 1956, altered by order dated September 28, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 500 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 11, 1956, as altered by Order dated September 28, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeals Nos. Cal. 208 and 223 of 1956, arising out of the Award dated June 7, 1956, of the Sixth Industrial Tribunal, Calcutta, in Case No. VIII-233 of 1955.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred an industrial dispute under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act to the second Industrial Tribunal on August 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the appeal are that on August 3, 1953, the Government of West Bengal referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, hereinafter called the Act, to the second Industrial Tribunal, an industrial dispute between the appellant and its workmen.

facts.text: Workmen surrounded and confined E. L. D'Cruz, acting Works Manager, from 9:15 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. on the day of the strike over Puja bonus dispute.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this Reference the workmen acted in a manner subversive of discipline, wilful insubordination and disobedience inasmuch as they surrounded by forming a kind of companydon round E. L. DCruz, acting Works Manager of the companypany, illegally companyfined him in a small place in the factory premises and kept him so companyfined between the hours of 9-15 a.m. to 2-15 p.m., till he was rescued by the police. The cause of this action on the part of the workmen is stated to be a dispute as to the payment of Puja bonus for the year 1953.

facts.text: Workmen went on strike at 9:15 a.m. on October 6, 1953, refused to resume work despite notices at 9:45 a.m. and 10:45 a.m., leading to lock-out after police arrival.

anchor.surface_text: The same day the workmen went on strike at 9-15 a.m. DCruz called upon them to resume work but they refused and the appellant- companypany issued numberices at 9-45 a. m., and 10-45 a.m. asking the workmen to resume work immediately. The workmen took numbernotice of these numberices and the appellant companypany after the arrival of the police declared a lock out. Some of the workmen were then arrested.

facts.text: Company served charge sheets on workmen, held enquiry, found 170 guilty of gross misconduct, sought permission under s.33 to dismiss from October 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany then served charge sheet on the workmen calling upon them to submit their explanations within 24 hours. The workmen gave numberexplanation. An enquiry was held and the workmen were found guilty of gross misconduct amounting to major misdemeanour which merited dismissal and the companypany proposed to dismiss them. For that purpose the appellant companypany on October 31,1953, made three applications Cal. Nos. 518, 519 and 557 of 1953 to the Tribunal for permission under s. 33 of the Act to dismiss 170 workmen with effect from October 6, 1953.

facts.text: Tribunal permitted dismissal of 3 workmen (Subbas Roy, Madhusudhan Rout, Bimal Kumar Ghose), refused for others due to doubt on identity and complicity.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal gave permission for the dismisSal of only three workmen Subbas Roy, Madhusudhan Rout and Bimal Kumar Ghose and permission with regard to the rest was refused on the ground that there was reasonable doubt as to their identity and companyplicity in the incident.

facts.text: Workmen applied under s.33A on January 8, 1954, allowed on July 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On January 8, 1954, the workmen made an application under s. 33A of the Act which was allowed on July 2, 1954.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal on March 29, 1955, dismissed company appeals under s.33, upheld 3 dismissals, set aside s.33A order.

anchor.surface_text: On March 29, 1955, the appeal of the companypany with regard to application under s. 33 of the Act was dismissed and so was the appeal of the workmen and thus the order as to 3 workmen was upheld. ... On the same day tile Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside the order of the Tribunal under s. 33A on the ground that the application under that section was misconceived and the order made by the Tribunal was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Company initiated fresh proceedings on April 20, 1955, sent registered notices to 64 workmen, affixed notices on boards inside and outside premises until June 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On April 20, 1955, the management of the appellant companypany took fresh proceedings against the 64 workmen and in order to serve charge sheets on them sent registered numberices to their addresses, registered with the appellant companypany, and also affixed numberices on its Notice Boards both inside the premises and outside the gate of the premises which remained affixed there from April 20, 1955, till June 9, 1955.

facts.text: Company terminated services of 64 workmen on June 22, 1955, after enquiry ended June 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry started by the management of the appellant companypany terminated on June 9, 1955, and as at that time numberproceedings were pending under the Act, the appellant companypany terminated the services of all the 64 workmen on June 22, 1955.

facts.text: West Bengal Government referred dispute on dismissal of 64 workmen on August 8, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The termination of the services of these workmen gave rise to an industrial dispute and a reference was made by the West Bengal Government on August 8, 1955, in regard to all the 64 workmen.

facts.text: Sixth Industrial Tribunal awarded on June 7, 1956: reinstated workmen Nos. 2-24 from April 1, 1955 with back wages; upheld dismissal of Nos. 25-48.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal  6th Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal  made its award on June 7, 1956. It held that the workmen Nos. 2 to 24 had number been properly served and ordered their reinstatement as from April 1, 1955, with back wages, dearness allowance, etc., from April 1, 1955, but upheld the dismissal of workmen Nos. 25 to 48.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal on September 11, 1956, dismissed company appeal, allowed union appeal, set aside dismissal of Nos. 25-48; amended September 28, 1956 to order reinstatement of 24 workmen with back wages from April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1956, the Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed the appeal of the appellant companypany and allowed that of the Union. ... The Appellate Tribunal suo motu amended this order on September 28, 1956, ... In other words we order the reinstatement of the twenty four workmen discharged by the Management with back wages for the period between the 1st of April, 1955, to the date of reinstatement .

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on October 17, 1958, allowing the appeal, setting aside LAT order and IT award for Nos. 2-24, upholding dismissals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal as to all the workmen and the award of the Industrial Tribunal as to workmen Nos. 2 to 24 are set aside and the claim for companypensation which was argued before us is disallowed.

facts.text: Strike on October 6, 1953 was illegal as reference was pending.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the strike of October 6, 1953, was illegal as at that time the reference was pending before the Industrial Tribunal

facts.text: Some workmen arrested on strike day.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the workmen were then arrested.

facts.text: Proceedings continued against 64 workmen after withdrawals, deaths, resignations; 47 remained (16 resigned, 1 pleaded guilty).

anchor.surface_text: Sixteen workmen resigned and one of them Haroo Haldar pleaded guilty and therefore proceedings were companytinued against only 47 workmen.

facts.text: Company wrote to Labour Commissioner on April 28, 1955, and to Union secretary on May 20, 1955, for addresses; no reply from secretary.

anchor.surface_text: On April 28, 1955, the appellant companypany wrote a letter to the Labour Commissioner informing him of the offences companymitted by the workmen and the action that it proposed to take against its workmen. On May 20, 1955, the appellant companypany wrote to the secretary of the Workers Union asking him for the addresses of the workmen who had number been served but it received numberreply from the secretary.

facts.text: LAT rejected E.L. D'Cruz evidence as he couldn't identify in 1954 but did in 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the evidence of E. L. DCruz given in the managerial enquiry in May 1955 companyld number be accepted. In its order the Appellate Tribunal said- In June 1954 Mr. E.L. DCruz was unable to give evidence against the appellants in Appeal No.Cal. 223 of 1956. In May 1955 he gave evidence companynecting the appellants with the misconduct

facts.text: Supreme Court found service of notices proper per standing orders, no violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: No principle of natural justice has, in our opinion, been infringed and the finding as to the workmen having numbernotice of the charges against them and companysequently number having a proper opportunity to meet the case against them cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Workmen Nos. 2-24 notices returned undelivered as addresses left or unknown.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the registered numberices sent numberices companyld number be served on workmen Nos. 2 to 24 and they were returned. to the sender with the remark that the addressees had either left or their addresses were unknown.

facts.text: Respondent No. 26 is dead.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the latter No. 26 is dead.

facts.text: Tribunal found prima facie case, bona fide action by company, no discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that a prima facie case had been made out for granting permission for dismissal of workmen directly involved in the incident that the appellant companypany had acted bona fide and that it was number guilty of discrimination, vindictiveness or arbitrary action.

facts.text: Sixth IT held identity established for Nos. 25-48, no bias or vindictiveness.

anchor.surface_text: It held that there was evidence to establish the identity of persons who had taken part in the strike and had wrongfully companyfined DCruz and that numberbias or illwill companyld be attributed to the management number was it inspired by any vindictive motives.

Cal. 208 and 223 of 1956, arising out of the Award dated June 7, 1956, of the Sixth Industrial Tribunal, Calcutta, in Case No. VIII-233 of 1955. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, D. N. Mukherjee and B. N. Ghosh, for the appellants.

The principles which govern the power of an Industrial Tribunal to interfere with the decision of the employer following an enquiry made by him were laid down by this Court in Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen where K. Das J., said at page138 Undoubtedly, the management of a concern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is not unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal interferes only on: (i) want of good faith; (ii) victimisation/unfair labour practice; (iii) basic error/violation of natural justice; (iv) completely baseless/perverse finding. None present here.

Das J., said at page138 Undoubtedly, the management of a companycern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is number unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief.

arguments.claim: s.33 proceedings prima facie only, no res judicata for s.10 adjudication

anchor.surface_text: That section does number companyfer any jurisdiction on a Tribunal to adjudicate on a dispute but it merely empowers the Tribunal to give or withhold permission to the employer during the pendency of an industrial dispute to discharge or punish a workman companycerned in the industrial dispute. And in deciding whether permission should or should number be given, the Industrial Tribunal is number to act as a reviewing tribunal against the decision of the management but to see that before it lifts the ban against the discharge or punishment of the workmen the employer makes out a Prima facie case.

holdings.text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal was in error in setting aside the order of the Industrial Tribunal on the ground that it was unable to accept the testimony of D'Cruz as to the identity of persons who had taken part in wrongfully confining him on the day of the illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Industrial Tribunal proceeded on correct principles as to its power in regard to an enquiry held by the management and the Labour Appellate Tribunal seems to have approached the question as if it was sitting in appeal against the decision taken by the management in regard to the termination of service of their workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Indian Iron & Steel principles limiting tribunal interference to lack of good faith, victimisation, basic error, natural justice violation, or perverse finding; none present; LAT sat in appeal on credibility.

holdings.text: No principle of natural justice has, in our opinion, been infringed and the finding as to the workmen having no notice of the charges against them and consequently no having a proper opportunity to meet the case against them cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: No principle of natural justice has, in our opinion, been infringed and the finding as to the workmen having no notice of the charges against them and consequently no having a proper opportunity to meet the case against them cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management complied with standing orders by affixing notices inside/outside, registered post, letters to union/labour commissioner; no extra required like newspaper ads.

holdings.text: The appellant company had done its best to serve the workmen and had complied with the standing orders and it was not necessary for the appellant to do anything more.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected need for union circulation or newspaper ads; standing orders service sufficient.

holdings.text: Any finding under s. 33 would not operate as res judicata and bar the raising of an industrial dispute nor is there anything in the section itself or in the findings arrived at by the Industrial Tribunal in s. 33 proceedings dated June 6, 1954, or of the Labour Appellate Tribunal dated March 29, 1955, which would debar the appellant company from holding the second enquiry or dismissing the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: That section does not confer any jurisdiction on a Tribunal to adjudicate on a dispute but it merely empowers the Tribunal to give or withhold permission to the employer during the pendency of an industrial dispute to discharge or punish a workman concerned in the industrial dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33 is prima facie permission to lift ban during pendency, not full adjudication; protects from victimisation; cites Atherton West, Lakshmi Devi, Automobile Products.

holdings.text: No basic error is therefore made out.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that this basic error does not seem to have been argued either before the Industrial Tribunal or the Labour Appellate Tribunal, on the other hand, the parties seem to have proceeded on the basis that the number of workmen proceeded against by the appellant company was 67 out of whom 64 were left after three were allowed to be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alleged numbers mismatch in confinement not argued below; parties proceeded on 67/64 basis.

holdings.text: Neither of the two sets of workmen is entitled to back wages by way of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: As we have come to the conclusion that the order of reinstatement by the Industrial Tribunal of workmen Nos. 2 to 24 and by the Appellate Tribunal of workmen Nos. 25 to 48 was erroneous, neither of the two sets of workmen is entitled to back wages by way of compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strike illegal, lockout justified; erroneous reinstatement orders.

holdings.text: This misconception as to the nature of the proceedings vitiated its order as the Appellate Tribunal misdirected itself as to the scope of the powers to be exercised by it and consequently it led to the making of an erroneous order.

anchor.surface_text: the managerial enquiry and further it was under a misapprehension as to the nature of the proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal and before itself, inasmuch as it seems to have been under the wrong impression that the appeal before it arose out

holdings.reasoning_summary: LAT confused s.10 reference with s.33/33A permission; amended order reflects s.33A misconception.

holdings.text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal as to all the workmen and the award of the Industrial Tribunal as to workmen Nos. 2 to 24 are set aside and the claim for compensation which was argued before us is disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal as to all the workmen and the award of the Industrial Tribunal as to workmen Nos. 2 to 24 are set aside and the claim for compensation which was argued before us is disallowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative errors by lower tribunals on enquiry validity, notice, res judicata, etc.; dismissals justified per management findings.

precedents.citation: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: After refering to the principles laid down in the case of Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its workmen 1 the Labour Appellate Tribunal ruled out the evidence of DCruz and as there was no other evidence to prove misconduct against the workmen, it came to the conclusion that the decision of the managment was perverse.

precedents.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: principles laid down regarding evidence in managerial enquiry

precedents.citation: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: The principles which govern the power of an Industrial Tribunal to interfere with the decision of the employer following an enquiry made by him were laid down by this Court in Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2 where K. Das J., said at page138

precedents.case_name: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: principles governing Industrial Tribunal's power to interfere with management's decision after domestic enquiry (want of good faith, victimisation, unfair labour practice, basic error or violation of natural justice, perverse finding)
precedents.cited_holding: Undoubtedly, the management of a concern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is not unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief. In cases of dismissal or misconduct, the Tribunal does not, however, act as a Court of appeal and substitute its own judgment for that of the management. It will interfere (i) when there is want of good faith, (ii) when there is victimisation or unfair labour practice, (iii) when the management has been guilty of a basic error or violation of a principle of natural justice, and (iv) when on the materials, the finding is completely baseless or perverse.

precedents.citation: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup

anchor.surface_text: In Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup which was a case under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950, this Court held that if it was established that the workmen had resorted to illegal strike,

precedents.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal would not interfere with management's order of dismissal if fair enquiry held without violating natural justice, workmen guilty of misconduct in illegal strike, and continuing them dangerous to company interests

precedents.citation: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das 2

anchor.surface_text: In Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das 2 it was held that no appeal lies against the order of an Industrial Tribunal where the Tribunal had examined the question whether the discretion of the employer to dismiss certain workmen was properly exercised,

precedents.case_name: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das
precedents.cited_proposition: no appeal against Tribunal's order examining employer's discretion to dismiss, bona fides, unfair labour practice, victimization, improper motive; management determines major misconduct per standing orders if facts support, good faith, no violation of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union 1 , Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills v. Pt. Ram Sarup 2 . In the Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala 3 4V44 Das J.,

precedents.case_name: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union
precedents.cited_proposition: nature and scope of proceedings under s.33; permission under s.33 does not bar raising industrial dispute after dismissal

precedents.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup
precedents.cited_proposition: nature and scope of proceedings under s.33; permission under s.33 does not bar raising industrial dispute after dismissal

precedents.citation: Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala 3

anchor.surface_text: In the Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala 3 4V44 Das J., as be then was said at p. 1256-- The purpose of these two sections (s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act) being to determine whether the ban should be removed or not,

precedents.case_name: Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala
precedents.cited_proposition: purpose of s.33 and s.22 is to accord or withhold permission to lift ban on discharge/punishment during pendency, not to adjudicate dispute; findings under s.33 not res judicata
precedents.cited_holding: The purpose of these two sections (s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act) being to determine whether the ban should be removed or not, all that is required of the authority exercising jurisdiction under these two sections is to accord or withhold permission.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal as to all the workmen and the award of the Industrial Tribunal as to workmen Nos. 2 to 24 are set aside and the claim for compensation which was argued before us is disa
